1280.41.text:
because they're able        
    to catch flies outside.

1283.68.text:
I've got some Trumpet      
     pitchers here.

1286.32.text:
If you were to take a       
    leaf and slice it open,

1288.85.text:
you would see that       
       this whole tube

1290.72.text:
is chocked full of flies    
    and things like that.

1296.69.text:
Toward the end of the summer,  
 they can be so full of bugs

1300.90.text: that the weight of the insects

1302.13.text:
will take these things     
     down to the ground.

1305.07.text:
They're very good        
       at what they do

1306.87.text: if you just give them a chance.

1309.71.text:
if you really don't have a    
  place to grow them outdoors,

1312.14.text:
you might want to catch     
    a fly every now and then

1318.15.text: have a nice array of insects

1322.75.text:
whether it's meal          
     worms or fruit flies,

1325.96.text:
- [Mary] So when they catch   
  the insects like that,

1328.89.text:
and it looks like they're    
   caught on the hair

1337.74.text:
- They actually do           
   release digestive fluids.

1340.64.text:
Even petunias, your average    
 petunia has hairs all over it.

1353.42.text:
That's a tough            
      question to answer.

1356.29.text:
All plants can absorb          
 nutrients through the leaves,

1359.86.text:
but they are considered     
    carnivorous plants,

1363.46.text:
they actually have fluids    
   that digest the prey.

1366.90.text:
What they're looking      
      for is nitrogen.

1373.24.text: and they need nitrogen to grow.

1376.47.text:
When they're catching      
     an insect, basically,

1378.11.text:
what they're trying to pull    
 out is the nitrogen from them.

1380.75.text:
What's left after          
     they're done feasting

1385.82.text:
so once they've            
     processed their food,

1388.82.text: a flytrap will open back up,

1390.69.text:
and the wind will blow     
     an insect's body away.

1394.76.text:
You know, it sloughs      
      off in the wind.

1397.16.text:
- [Mary] Does it hurt the    
   plants to touch the pads?

1401.10.text:
- Yeah, it's not a       
       good idea at all.

1403.50.text:
That's a big thing,          
   especially with children,

1405.97.text:
because they like         
      to see that action.

1408.04.text:
That's why most          
       people have them,

1411.11.text:
but the traps can          
     only close maybe two,

1413.48.text:
or three, or four        
       times in its life,

1415.75.text:
so after it's been          
    sprung that many times,

1418.52.text:
the trap is going to      
      turn black and die.

1421.32.text:
If you've been just teasing   
  it with your finger,

1424.12.text:
it obviously won't have any   
  food to help it to grow.

1430.56.text:
and you're not adding to     
   the plant's need for food,

1435.93.text:
then the plant will       
      succumb slowly.

1438.20.text: It's just not a good thing.

1439.54.text:
As far as plants like      
     these sundews go,

1442.17.text:
they've got these sticky    
    little glands all over

1449.78.text: that helps it to catch insects.

1451.95.text:
- [Mary] If you have      
      these in the house,

1456.15.text:
If you put them outside,    
    what kind of light

1457.46.text:
should you put them       
      into out there?

1466.46.text: If you grow the Pitcher plants

1472.90.text:
They don't hold           
      themselves up nice.

1475.64.text: They don't color up as well.

1477.17.text:
You can see a lot        
       of these plants

1479.48.text:
have beautiful, red       
      coloring in them,

1481.98.text: and you won't have that coloring

1484.45.text:
if you don't grow        
       them in full sun.

1486.68.text:
- [Mary] How do you know      
  if you have to re-pot them?

1488.62.text:
- Re-potting really isn't      
 something that has to be done

1493.53.text:
If they start to get so big   
  that they're growing out

1494.96.text:
of their pot, they're       
    spilling over the edge,

1497.40.text:
and it looks like it's     
     painful for the plant

1500.70.text:
then you would want       
      to re-pot them.

1502.90.text:
You're going to want to     
    use plastic, or glass,

1507.87.text:
You don't want to        
       use any clay pots

1512.24.text:
because you're trying       
    to hold the moisture in,

1513.78.text:
unlike with, say,           
    bromeliads and orchids,

1516.78.text:
where you want the       
       plant to dry off

1520.79.text:
These plants you want        
   them to hold the moisture.

1522.95.text:
You'd want to grow them     
    in a tray of water,

1525.66.text:
maybe an inch of water in    
   the bottom of the tray,

1537.40.text:
This is the Northern      
      Pitcher plant here.

1542.41.text:
Pretty much throughout the    
  northern half of the state,

1544.51.text: there's lots of bogs out there,

1548.28.text:
and if you go out        
       hiking in a bog,

1550.68.text:
you're going to have to     
    deal with bugs and heat

1554.49.text:
but you could easily stumble   
 across one of these beauties.

1557.92.text: So that is native to Minnesota?

1561.29.text:
as well as this little,     
    round-leaf sundew here,

1564.66.text: which is kind of hard to find.

1567.53.text: Right in there, this little guy.

1569.07.text:
They only grow maybe an     
    inch or two in diameter,

1574.71.text:
but they're also          
      native to Minnesota.

1576.74.text:
- That really looks like     
   a miniature Venus flytrap.

1579.55.text:
- Well, it's a             
     sundew, so it's a pad

1582.08.text:
with lots of sticky       
      things like this.

1584.75.text:
Considering that one of      
   the most important things

1587.28.text: with us being the hot spot,

1592.26.text:
they all live here         
     in the United States.

1595.66.text:
With a lot of them living    
   in the north climate,

1599.67.text:
what's important is that      
  they have a winter dormancy.

1604.00.text:
Orchids and bromeliads       
   may slow down their growth

1608.07.text:
these plants actually      
     need to shut down.

1609.91.text:
I keep them, like 37,      
     38 degrees all winter.

1618.22.text: and they sort of die down.

1619.65.text:
They go into a            
      very dormant state.

1621.62.text:
These would be buried      
     under the snow,

1626.59.text:
Pitcher plants will        
     put up their flowers.

1628.66.text:
This is what's left       
      of the flower stalk.

1632.80.text:
They put up their flowers    
   early in the spring,

1636.80.text:
and then after the        
      flower's pollinated,

1638.87.text: and the seed pod starts forming,

1640.91.text:
that's when they put      
      up their pitchers.

1642.84.text:
So in that way, they're not   
  eating their pollinators,

1648.98.text:
All of these                 
   demonstrations and plants

1650.98.text:
that you have shown us      
    have been so wonderful.

1654.32.text:
Thank you so much         
      for letting us come

1656.29.text:
and learn all about        
     these unusual plants.
